comments.commentBody: I think some of your comments are rather harsh. Areas of our country deal with unemployment rates that are too high as well....but we are also a country with a social safety net that offers support at those times. We too have immigrants willing to do jobs for lower wages and 2nd or 3rd generation Canadians who may feel entitled to better paying jobs. And we have yet to solve those disparities. But we need immigration because our population growth is not enough to support our future. Knowing many Canadians who have gone to live and work in your country, I haven't heard them be self- righteous but actually appreciative of the opportunities. And your country can be quite selective about who they take in.
Actually thorough screening has been done but has your own country clearly demonstrates on a regular basis, home grown terrorists are a greater threat.

Eleanor - When I was volunteering at the settlement society, one of the questions I was asked was about the small size of Canadian families. My answer was the children are expensive and so Canadians don't have so many because they want to provide well for each one. There was a moment of thoughtful silence. That had not really been an issue for the people I was talking to, and a new one for them to consider here, where they could hope that their kids would have better education opportunities. Families get smaller as education levels and income go up.

Planned Parenthood exists in Canada but is not the default reproductive care provider for poor people. Canadians all have access to a family doctor that has no user fees or co-pays. That *socialist* medicine you know.

Religion does not play such a significant role in our country as it does in yours so with time, these differences will be manageable. We are very much a secular country without prayer in our schools or expecting our politicians to declare their faith and bless us after every speech.
You are incorrect. The private sponsorship program goes back to when Vietnamese refugees came to Canada 35-40 years ago.
Read it? I could write it. Surely at this point anyone who's been paying attention to the NY Times could. Or was there something the least bit unexpected?
With all of the refugees and immigrants you have had come to your country over decades and centuries, that is your take away from this article?

Unfortunately, there will be collateral damage when fighting any war.  When fighting the Muslim terrorist cowards, who hide behind women and children, the number of so-called civilian casualties will be greater, however, these civilians may not truly be civilians because while they are not soldiers, they are willing to serve as a shield for the terrorists.  The choice is to fight the terrorists in their homeland, or to allow them to kill us in our homeland.  While the truth is sometimes difficult to accept, we are at war, and it is either them or us.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
The politically correct side of Mr. Obama has always felt that innocents should not die in war, a feeling we ALL generally start out with until most of us realize how dangerous this sentiment can ironically become to those near the fighting.

The statements he made repeatedly in the sales campaign for Obamacare were clearly understood by everyone in the West Wing to be absolute lies, and the staff discussed this with him because, as we know, the lies were soon exposed.
But Barack insisted that the ends justified the means and that people would ignore being taken advantage of when the results were counted.

Of course, lying is not only a sin against God but a violation of the trust that the people have in their government. One result of Mr. Obama's attitude about lying is that the share of Americans feeling proud of their country has dropped from 70% to 50% under this arrogant huckster.

King Charles II and Marie Antoinette also saw their government lose its credibility with the French.
His being an ineffectual loser in international affairs is just icing on the cake.
BUT his approach shots are looking much better, if that helps.

It is rather difficult to view this administration as credible given how honest and transparent Bush, Cheney, Rice and Rumsfeld were,  Not to mention the absolute trustworthiness of the Bush 41 and Reagan administrations!

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
No, you can't charge Mr. Obama with this attitude or pattern of mistakes. He leads the way in trying to reduce the deaths of the innocent - some would say too much.
But there is a long line of people making decisions between Mr. Obama and the joysticks and keyboards scattered around the U.S. A.F. Stuff just happens, and we can't know everything under those roofs or inside those vehicles.
Yes, but if the drone drops my pizza, no one is going to die.
Then we shall get used to the hatred of those civilians impacted by our drone strikes to revert back to us in one form or another as well.

"So next time Americans are murdered in the name of ISIS by a killer "
ISIS is the junior varsity that is contained, so don't worry about them.

"If somebody was sending rockets into my house where my two daughters sleep at night, I'm going to do everything in my power to stop that."

-then-Senator Barack Obama, speech in Sderot, Israel, 2008

So next time Americans are murdered in the name of ISIS by a killer who references one of our many our bombing campaigns in some distant land, spare the surprise and outrage. And be thankful they don't have drones. Yet.
And if you don't like drones, you'll love the next step in warfare, cyber attacks on electricty grids, communication grids, water supplies. You ain't seen nothing yet!

Why does it matter whether a drone strike killed a civilian or a bomb or missile killed him? There are always innocent deaths and injuries. As American citizens, the only question we should ask ourselves is whether or not we want our leaders to engage in military actions in other countries, and if so, to what extent, for what purpose and for how long. I believe we would do much more good for our own security and that of civilians in the region by stopping the flow of money, weapons and oil to ISIS operators. We surely have the economic power to do that.

You obviously don't drive in heavy traffic with all the reckless driving behavior out there. Those passenger jets you fly on are self driving. Give me an AI self driver on the road over 80% of the human drivers even with current technology!

I see drinking the Kool-Ade and spouting the headline rhetoric is far more preferable for you than looking at what is really happening.  Like many, you have become a finger pointing lemming (urban definition).  Gather the facts.  The data point.  Not just the ones that appear to fit or can be made to fit your "opinion".  Then make an informed statement.
Billy I highly recommend you stay in bed. The world is too dangerous for you.

comments.userLocation: up in the woods down by the river
comments.commentBody:
We've been blinded by the glare of technology and corporate worship. Our regulators have lost all common sense. What is billed as a safety advancement is deployed by a corporation without any oversight from government regulators. Like everyone else they're staring at their phones distracted from reality by data, stats and analytics to the point where once again industry regulates government rather than the other way around.

If a corporation chooses to circumvent pesky laws and regulations all they need do to bypass them is embed the crime in a software app and then issue an update if they get caught. Or when somebody dies.
If the car breaks the law or injures someone who is at fault?  Who gets the ticket?  Elon Musk?  The computer programmer?  The person in the driver's seat?

I disagree. The bias of the times is pretty apparent related to politics, but I find the scientific judgements rather sound. I appreciate having a conversation related to 'advanced' technology versus actual advances. Tesla over sells. Don't blame the company, but they could really use a little humility and exercise some honesty in their operations. Never should label as 'Autonomous'. Should be 'assist' if they want to be true to the current technology.

Anyone who has payed attention through the years to NYTimes coverage of electric vehicles will be aware of its bias against this new technology.  The paper is not a big fan of solar, either.  It is, in fact, as stodgy in its view of new technology and tech culture as it is in its Clinton-era politics.

Range Anxiety is the bane of all electric cars- including Tesla. Experienced same with my Early Prius. Liked the nice driving and smoothness. A good idea that needs encouragement- not disparagement, JGAIA
How do u know that, Charles? Nobody knows the future.
I would love to see all the improvements you suggest.  Get back to me when you succeed.  In the meantime I'll be driving my Tesla.
Always appreciate the millennials who couldn't care less about the elderly, the disabled, and the physically limited who can't participate in their bicycle revolution.

Yes. It's crazy to think that 250 million cars and trucks in the US will be magically be replaced by electric vehicles without enormous damage to the environment. Probably fifteen years to turn over half the fleet. And that's not even answering the question of where all this extra electricity is coming from, when we're struggling now to get 15% of the electricity that we currently "need" from renewables.

Looking at the big picture, even more problems with the environment associated with the individual vehicle, whether electric or now, self-navigating or not, including: sprawl and loss of crop land and biodiversity; storm water runoff as well as large energy inputs associated with roads and parking lots; large houses with mountains of junk contained within; trillions of dollars spent on health care that are unavailable to spend on other things, etc.

Just another example of wanting something for nothing. Still stuck in a "paper or plastic?" mindset. We know how to arrange our built environment to minimize negative impacts on the natural environment: compact, walkable towns and cities. Which happen to go hand in hand with public transportation systems, and they don't even require passengers to drive.

Or, we could invest in better public transportation both nationally and state-wide, put a very high tax on gasoline, and develop safer, more clarified bike paths to discourage auto driving altogether.

But that'd just make too much sense; besides, public transportation and the physical activity associated with using it, would, frighteningly enough, help us overcome our morbid obesity epidemic.

The nerve!
Yes, indeed. Blame the little guy. Old story.

People should not be associating this incident with self-driving cars - something that responsible technology companies and automakers are working on. This was not a self-driving car, it was a human driven car. Autopilot is an aid similar to cruise control, it is not meant to be a hands-free experience and any accidents that happen when a car is in auto-pilot are the fault of the driver, not the computer. People are right to question why these cars were ever allowed on the road with this feature enabled, but it is a separate discussion from self-driving cars.
Meanwhile the entire automobile world is trying to build a "Tesla-killer." Maybe you have a thing about alternative energy.
